item.title: Epstein-Barr Virus Infection Promotes Epithelial Cell Growthby Attenuating Differentiation-Dependent Exit from the Cell Cycle
Obligatory how to do a blogdown-like-website post
item.description:
I tend to repeat myself a lot, but I guess that there are many resources explaining how to do a website with blogdown. So, I will list all of the resources that I followed:

  1. blogdown, creating websites with R markdown, this book explains pretty much all the details. The chapter that I had to pay the most attention was the one about deployment of the website.

  2. Alison Hill’s Up & Running with blogdown, a graphical guide on how to set up the website, starting from the github repository, and ending on how to custom CSS, using formspree, or even adapting the domain to be .rbind.io

  3. Leslie Myint’s Tips for using the Hugo academic theme. This post was key to learn how to pick the right colors on the configuration of the site, and the code chunks

I used the Hugo Academic’s theme, which is more powerful than what I did for this site, but to keep things simple, almost all the files that need to be edited are in the content folder.

  • The main page is in content/authors/admin/_index.md

  • The posts are in content/post, and to generate a new post the blogdown’s addin does everything except writing a new post.

  • I used the content/project directory to keep the Software tab, and it is only necessary to create a folder for every software project, and edit one of the index.md files that come by default when creating an academic blog project. The picture was added as a file name featured.png in the same folder.

  • The content/publication works similarly, but we can also add a cite.bib / a pdf version of the paper, etc.

More details on how to configure the site are available in the academic site’s documentation, I hope this is useful!

item.title: Slides
item.description:
Welcome to Slides

Academic

Features

  • Efficiently write slides in Markdown
  • 3-in-1: Create, Present, and Publish your slides
  • Supports speaker notes
  • Mobile friendly slides

Controls

  • Next: Right Arrow or Space
  • Previous: Left Arrow
  • Start: Home
  • Finish: End
  • Overview: Esc
  • Speaker notes: S
  • Fullscreen: F
  • Zoom: Alt + Click
  • PDF Export: E

Code Highlighting

Inline code: variable

Code block:

porridge = "blueberry"
if porridge == "blueberry":
    print("Eating...")

Math

In-line math: $x + y = z$

Block math:

$$ f\left( x \right) = \;\frac{{2\left( {x + 4} \right)\left( {x - 4} \right)}}{{\left( {x + 4} \right)\left( {x + 1} \right)}} $$

Fragments

Make content appear incrementally

{{% fragment %}} One {{% /fragment %}}
{{% fragment %}} **Two** {{% /fragment %}}
{{% fragment %}} Three {{% /fragment %}}

Press Space to play!

One Two Three

A fragment can accept two optional parameters:

  • class: use a custom style (requires definition in custom CSS)
  • weight: sets the order in which a fragment appears

Speaker Notes

Add speaker notes to your presentation

{{% speaker_note %}}
- Only the speaker can read these notes
- Press `S` key to view
{{% /speaker_note %}}

Press the S key to view the speaker notes!

  • Only the speaker can read these notes
  • Press S key to view

Themes

  • black: Black background, white text, blue links (default)
  • white: White background, black text, blue links
  • league: Gray background, white text, blue links
  • beige: Beige background, dark text, brown links
  • sky: Blue background, thin dark text, blue links
  • night: Black background, thick white text, orange links
  • serif: Cappuccino background, gray text, brown links
  • simple: White background, black text, blue links
  • solarized: Cream-colored background, dark green text, blue links

Custom Slide

Customize the slide style and background

{{< slide background-image="/img/boards.jpg" >}}
{{< slide background-color="#0000FF" >}}
{{< slide class="my-style" >}}

Custom CSS Example

Let’s make headers navy colored.

Create assets/css/reveal_custom.css with:

.reveal section h1,
.reveal section h2,
.reveal section h3 {
  color: navy;
}

item.title: Tidy loading of RData files in parallel
item.description:
In my last project, I have been using this function very frequently:

load2env <- function(file,env = new.env())
{
  load(file,envir = env)
  env
}

This function loads the RData file into the environment env, which will usually return. However, if we have multiple files to load simultaneously, when trying to load multiple files in parallel we would run into an error, because it would be creating many environments at the same time.

Using the new furrr or any other package that allows parallel processing, and creating the environments in advance, we can load many RData files in paralele by using:

library(furrr)

plan(multiprocess)

my_data = tibble(
  files = list.files( my_dir ,full.names = TRUE )) %>% 
  mutate(
    env = map(files,  ~ new.env()),
    data = future_map2( files, env, load2env   ) %>% 
      map(as.list)
  )

item.title: Plotting manhattan plots and LD matrices together in R
item.description:
Genomic Wide Association Studies have been used to identify robust associations between phenotype and genotypes. However, these studies are hard to interpret because positions in the genome are usually correlated. For that purpose, we would like to compare the signal’s strength and the correlation between the SNPs at the same time.

When I looked for tools to make these plots, I only found the LDheatmap which is capable of plotting the heatmap but not adding it to a manhattan plot.

library(tidyverse)
library(scales)
library(grid)
library(gridExtra)

theme_set(theme_minimal())

For the purpose of this post, I cleaned eQTL p.values for one loci.

plot_data
## # A tibble: 14 x 3
##    SNP             pos eQTL_log10pval
##    <chr>         <int>          <dbl>
##  1 rs10864454 10417853          -15.2
##  2 rs12135774 10386506          -13.4
##  3 rs1220400   9997079          -55.6
##  4 rs1234694  10003320          -99.4
##  5 rs3820192  11847772          -19.4
##  6 rs41275494 11894133          -14.3
##  7 rs4240912  10437778          -13.8
##  8 rs55741089 11898859          -14.0
##  9 rs55867221 11845222          -19.4
## 10 rs56001051 11838841          -19.4
## 11 rs6670157  10458439          -12.4
## 12 rs6688187  11837473          -19.4
## 13 rs6703535  11843919          -19.4
## 14 rs72638698 11835455          -19.4
mat_data
## # A tibble: 196 x 6
##    SNP1       SNP2          cor     pos1    pos2 abs_dist
##    <chr>      <chr>       <dbl>    <int>   <int>    <int>
##  1 rs1220400  rs1220400  1.      9997079 9997079        0
##  2 rs1234694  rs1220400  0.952  10003320 9997079     6241
##  3 rs10864454 rs1220400 -0.102  10417853 9997079   420774
##  4 rs12135774 rs1220400 -0.0985 10386506 9997079   389427
##  5 rs3820192  rs1220400 -0.0474 11847772 9997079  1850693
##  6 rs41275494 rs1220400 -0.0489 11894133 9997079  1897054
##  7 rs4240912  rs1220400 -0.0426 10437778 9997079   440699
##  8 rs55741089 rs1220400 -0.0473 11898859 9997079  1901780
##  9 rs55867221 rs1220400 -0.0557 11845222 9997079  1848143
## 10 rs56001051 rs1220400 -0.0670 11838841 9997079  1841762
## # … with 186 more rows

The first steps are to make the plots by separate:

plot1 = plot_data %>% 
  ggplot(aes(pos,-eQTL_log10pval))+
  geom_point()+
  scale_x_continuous(labels = comma)
plot1

snp_levels = mat_data %>% 
    dplyr::select(SNP1,pos1) %>% 
    unique() %>% 
    arrange(pos1) %>% 
    pluck("SNP1")

plot2 = mat_data %>% 
  dplyr::filter(pos1 >= pos2) %>% 
  mutate_at(vars(contains("SNP")),funs(factor(.,levels = snp_levels))) %>% 
    ggplot(
      aes(SNP1,SNP2,fill = cor^2))+
    geom_tile()+
    theme(legend.position = "right")+
    scale_fill_distiller(palette = "Spectral",
                         guide = guide_colourbar(title = expression(R^2),
                                                 barheight = unit(0.4,"npc"),
                                                 barwidth = unit(0.03,"npc")))+
    theme(
      axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 90)
    )+
    xlab("SNP")+ylab("SNP")+coord_fixed()
plot2

This plot requires some cleaning work, we first remove the labels from the axis:

plot2_clean = plot2 +
    theme(legend.position = "none",
        axis.title = element_blank(),
        panel.grid = element_blank(),
        plot.background = element_blank(),
        panel.border = element_blank(),
        axis.text.y = element_blank(),
        axis.text.x = element_blank())
plot2_clean

snp_data = mat_data %>% 
  dplyr::filter(SNP1 == SNP2)

plot2_clean = plot2_clean +
  geom_text(
    data = snp_data,aes(label = SNP1),size =3,angle = -45,hjust = 1,
    nudge_x = -.5,nudge_y = .5,show.legend = FALSE)
plot2_clean

We almost have the pieces, so we arrange everything together by using gridExtra:

## extract the legend
aux_grob = ggplotGrob(plot2)$grobs
legend = aux_grob[[which(sapply(aux_grob,function(x)x$name) == "guide-box")]]

## rotate the LD matrix
bottom_part = arrangeGrob(plot2_clean,vp = viewport(angle = -45)) 

## overlap the empty part of the LD matrix (which requires theme_minimal) and
## included a bit of space at the bottom
whole_plot = arrangeGrob(plot1 +
                           theme(axis.title.x = element_blank()),
                         textGrob(""),
                         bottom_part,textGrob(""),
                         ncol =1,heights = c(5,-2,10,2))
grid.newpage()
grid.arrange(whole_plot,legend,nrow = 1,widths = c(9,1))

The result is a publication ready figure that shows 14 snps are clustered into at least 4 clusters.

item.title: ChIPexoQual
item.description:
ChIP-exo/nexus experiments rely on innovative modifications of the commonly used ChIP-seq protocol for high resolution mapping of transcription factor binding sites. Although many aspects of the ChIP-exo data analysis are similar to those of ChIP-seq, these high throughput experiments pose a number of unique quality control and analysis challenges. We develop a novel statistical quality control pipeline and accompanying R/Bioconductor package, ChIPexoQual, to enable exploration and analysis of ChIP-exo and related experiments. ChIPexoQual evaluates a number of key issues including strand imbalance, library complexity, and signal enrichment of data. Assessment of these features are facilitated through diagnostic plots and summary statistics computed over regions of the genome with varying levels of coverage.

The package is available in Bioconductor

item.description:
An R package to visualize ChIP-seq experiments across a set of pre-defined peaks. The package requires a set of pre-defined genomic regions, and aligned reads in bam format. We can do many tasks with it, some examples are:

  • Extracts read data of specified input regions
  • Plot peaks of different conditions across the same set of regions
  • Plot central measures for a set of regions with the same width
  • Subset regions according to used defined annotations
  • Plot the heatmap of signal curves accross regions separated by annotation

The package is available here
